Problem:
Consider a system governed by the complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \\), where \\( \omega \) is a real constant representing angular frequency. Investigate how the Fourier transform affects this system, particularly through a transformation \\( F(z) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty z(t) e^{-i \omega' t} dt \\) where \\( \omega' \\) is the variable of transformation.

If the system starts with the complex function \\( z(t) \\) and evolves over time without any intervention, will the result of the Fourier transform \\( F(z) \\) at frequency \\( \omega' \\) be a delta function centered at \\( \omega \\)?
Explanation: When the system evolving as \\( e^{i \omega t} \\) is subjected to the Fourier transform, the inherent properties of the transform and the specific frequency \\( \omega \\) of the function result in a delta function \\( \delta(\omega - \omega') \\), indicating the transform's ability to isolate the frequency component exactly matching \\( \omega \\).
